importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the latest update in the UN's call for improved global early-warning systems amid escalating extreme weather events.

This date corresponds to the mountain glacier collapse in Switzerland, which was predicted through monitoring and led to the evacuation of the village of Blatten, demonstrating the real-world impact of early warnings.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The year 2025 is highlighted as a period of extreme weather events globally, including flooding in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, underscoring the urgency of early warning systems.
The WMO's annual conference in Geneva in 2025 serves as a key moment for global policy discussion on disaster preparedness and climate resilience.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, increasing vulnerability—especially in developing nations.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of fatalities occurring in developing countries over the past 50 years.
Weather, water, and climate-related hazards have caused over 2 million deaths globally in the past 50 years.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most dire in fragile, conflict-affected regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning alert websites and standardized warnings.
Early warnings enable early action, which is vital to saving lives and protecting infrastructure.
The collapse of a Swiss glacier in May 2025, predicted through monitoring, led to the evacuation of Blatten, demonstrating the effectiveness of early warning systems in real-world scenarios.
Permafrost melt and glacier instability are increasing risks, reinforcing the need for global investment in monitoring and alert systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has called for urgent improvements in global early-warning systems for extreme weather, highlighting that nearly half of all countries lack such systems—leaving millions, especially in developing nations, exposed to life-threatening disasters. The WMO reports that weather, water, and climate-related hazards have killed over 2 million people in the past 50 years, with 90% of deaths occurring in developing countries. While there has been progress—such as 108 countries now using early warnings—the situation remains dire, with half of 62 assessed countries having only basic capacity. The article underscores the real-world impact of early warnings, citing the successful evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten in May 2025 after a glacier collapse was predicted through monitoring. The WMO emphasizes that early warnings must translate into early action to save lives and protect infrastructure as climate change intensifies extreme weather globally.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
